title: Self-Regulation: A Foundation of Development
subject: Early Learning Guidelines: Birth to Age 3 (2012-)

document.title: Illinois Early Learning Guidelines For Children Birth to Age Three

F4EB1CC32DA74A87870A8B06FEC23B47.description:
Demonstrates an awareness of expectations, e.g., approaches
and gently touches a baby, waits for brief periods of time when
turn-taking

792CFFCBC7894A24B28BAC8779B6CDBA.description: Checks in with caregiver through nonverbal and verbal communication, e.g., glances, waves, points, says name, asks a question, all without having to be in close proximity

0F14BEFECE3E4A068D0D9D17F2A2A88C.description: Transitions smoothly if is prepared ahead of time

0CAFCD2397B640288F8E851A9500C182.description:
Identifies situations where he or she needs the caregiver to
support in controlling behavior, e.g., holds caregiver’s hand
when crossing the street

6A0123C0B8464B9F961C301D422D9278.description:
Increasingly reacts appropriately to adults’ facial expressions,
tone, and affect, before acting on an impulse

5FBC664B5D5040F18BCEAECF2350BC71.description: Increases the use of private speech in everyday play and interactions

364DEAE2204A4B6CABDFB4F3AED4F38A.description:
Begins to respond to caregiver’s cues and modifies behavior,
e.g., does not touch the forbidden object, once recognizing the
caregiver is discouraging the action

D4AF98B507E24CED92CA3E379DA174FF.description: Communicates “no” to self when reaching for forbidden objects

BE19EF4F7AE5403FAF88C9625DD383DD.description: Communicates “mine” when another child takes a toy away

5AF39B9AB544475FA11A51889FEF1C00.description:
Completes a forbidden action regardless of referencing a
caregiver’s reaction, e.g., looks toward their caregiver before
touching the forbidden object and then touches it anyway

A38B488245C1482093207953B0825207.description:
Chooses between two options, e.g., “You can have the red ball
or the blue ball”

6A24C9E2359D4A878726C92E0728C832.description:
Has difficulty channeling excitement, e.g., screams, jumps,
squeezes, bites

A3EE535C0DA64344966FCA688C54CA12.description:
Reads cues and body language of caregiver(s) and familiar
others to guide reactions and behaviors in novel and uncertain
situations

345C7245790D4D25AD3150E6D4BE17AF.description:
Explores environment while unaware of boundaries and limits,
e.g., crawls toward a shelf and attempts to climb it

220D92495E9B4A71A9F88543EA9369B8.description:
Shows curiosity and limited restraint when exploring the environment, e.g., reaches for objects that adults or other children
are holding

18BE1054D33A4306B2BBF12BDA3A29F0.description:
Physically explores environment through touch, e.g., sucking,
gnawing, hitting, pulling, banging

5AAB5FC4AA644F398198F18CE17DA666.description:
Uses physical movements to disengage from interaction, turns
head, averts gaze

C37BDEE26C4F4C30B0176D94223E3DC4.description: Cries when hungry, tired, uncomfortable, or bored

223D1EBF39F3457F80D781040B0EF78B.description:
Children demonstrate the emerging ability to manage and adjust behaviors in accordance with social and cultural
contexts.

EFF9C87B010C4F95A4F1FB23BF015840.description:
Transitions between what he or she is engaged in and what is
happening in the background, e.g., makes a comment in regard
to a conversation happening between another child and adult,
while engaged in completing a puzzle

CC3854EA86424049BDE0D2A373F0221B.description: Wait time increases, e.g., participates in turn-taking activities

67F8EB91AB4A4B749306FF7B04CF5F35.description:
Plays independently before moving on to a new activity, e.g.,
engages in block play, reads a book

A63C2A8320F74C9C8F729838527DE7CB.description:
Uses self-talk to extend play, e.g., says “now sleepy” to the baby
doll after feeding it a bottle

75BAEF42C43B45528F9D7ECAE63171D0.description:
Attention expands and stays focused on an activity or object
even when distractions are present

97B2D8B2F9DC44B694902E9F65261CB8.description:
Attends and stays engaged to often reach a goal, e.g., places all
the shapes in the shape sorter

7ABC5FD208FB415B959EB1D53B14C1C1.description:
Remains focused for longer periods of time while engaged in
self-initiated play

ED5D34FCEF8943D4BDEC654676AB7173.description:
Works on solving increasingly difficult activities, e.g., attempts
to solve a simple, three-piece puzzle

CFBF37C9EC1A46D0B410CD921FE81C04.description:
Works to find solutions to simple problems and/or obstacles,
e.g., attempts to climb onto a piece of furniture in order to
retrieve a toy

0B6BE8B9E2B14156997C8A807D82E81C.description:
Relies on routines and patterns to maintain an organized state in
order to focus

B57ABC41D7CD47CEA597E379809E67FE.description: Shifts attention from adults to peers

68FDC7CC32AB4F858E046D48D072ACD2.description:
Focuses on one object or activity for a brief period of time, even
with other objects close in proximity; still easily distracted

266C4F995BB7463B8B9460EFF7B975F6.description:
Maintains more advanced levels of engagement, e.g., repeats
actions over and over when enjoying the reaction and result of
the experience

6380510FEBC646E5B7406F2B48641B83.description:
Engages in joint attention with a caregiver, e.g. joins in looking
at the same object or shifts gaze to where someone is pointing

58FC419AEEE14744A3355D2D7D1A01F2.description:
Plays with one object for a few minutes before focusing on a
different object

803418F53CCB4F638E819409AEDF000A.description: Focuses attention on novel objects and familiar caregiver(s)

8AA9F3D09A11414288AE5D715F13AC10.description:
Explores environment through senses, e.g., touches and mouths
objects

7808DE1316DD47DB87E9168BC5023829.description:
Initiates and briefly maintains social interactions with adults,
e.g., establishes eye contact, coos to receive attention

DD58260CCDFE47C1907037F24EA33518.description: Focuses on objects in the environment during alert states

A44E750761C44F91A220E94C4D7EB98C.description:
Children demonstrate the emerging ability to process stimuli, focus and sustain attention, and maintain engagement in
accordance with social and cultural contexts.

6E86849552E64997ADEC0CDEAD528909.description:
Holds on to a special object during certain times of the day, e.g.,
blanket, picture, book, stuffed toy

CEA092E72B0B43D2BCE3611AFED2DC89.description: Expresses emotions through the use of play

AE690DE9BB874F15BAF35F61BABBD980.description:
Seeks caregiver support when feeling overwhelmed by emotion;
may reject support as well

6C7CEACF7B1243E2A99549BC2D6693A4.description:
Engages in pretend play to manage uncertainty and fear, e.g.,
plays doctor and gives someone a “shot”

73B6EAC7E1B74FD48E3253A9FDD7330A.description: Communicates wants and needs verbally, e.g. “pick me up”

A3E2073792204B9682AB06B5D08FF2DC.description:
Begins to use “private speech” in order to assist in regulating
their emotions, e.g., utters “bear, where is bear” to self

1252B79E54A44C7285DBD9A0A69558C5.description:
Uses verbal and nonverbal communication to signal the need for
their caregiver, e.g., calls by name, crawls into a familiar adult’s lap

61FC92958D0B4713BD9E3AE4DA332A67.description:
Uses play to sort out feelings and gain control over them, e.g.,
projects feeling onto an object, grasps a ball and hugs it tightly
to chest when excited

A250BE71D7004CD7ADB0ECF6D06610E2.description:
Uses caregiver’s facial cues and body language to assist in novel
and uncertain situations, e.g., sees a dog for the first time and
uses the adult’s smile as a cue to cautiously pat the dog

B2AFA6E60E1D48A5A0AB60303D4D5AFB.description:
Uses comfort objects, e.g., a stuffed animal or blanket, to help
calm down

3851482CD1CC4BCC94349CCAE010A2AB.description:
Seeks out caregiver through physical actions, e.g., reaches for
the caregiver’s hand or moves closer to them when frightened

844D71B8342B4F7496324B7DCABA6E62.description: Prefers physical proximity to familiar adults in unknown situations, e.g., follows caregiver when he or she leaves the room

85D4DF3B44514CE08062ED03A537E714.description:
Uses social referencing in uncertain situations, e.g., looks at a
caregiver’s face for reassurance in the presence of a new person

8102539D22954AC58CB0679E3262AEA0.description:
Able to self-soothe more effectively, e.g., sucks thumb, holds on
to stuffed toy

D64887D661D942A39335E91D123C7B0A.description: Communicates needs to an adult, e.g., points, shakes head

C0D5F55738BD42CF9AD5381146616462.description:
Vocalizes and uses facial cues to get caregiver’s attention, e.g.,
cries, gazes, initiates eye contact

760B64596C7249F9BDA3259A4D2E49A3.description:
Begins to use self-soothing strategies, e.g., sucks on hands,
grasps an object in order to calm self

E9BB73995C0045A1B0102B2C4D10FE16.description:
Able to use cues to signal overstimulation , e.g., turns head,
gaze aversion

D9EF9F5A9CA6494DB2087D88D240DE0A.description: Signals needs by sounds and movement

94396704C08F49008F1DAE5ED22E2CBE.description:
Children demonstrate the emerging ability to identify and manage the expression of emotion in accordance with social
and cultural contexts.

CD8A39AE9F7C4403B59DC83449659E0D.description: Demonstrates a readiness to begin toilet training

BBE28558D4154BA8A80E27C7E70BD6D3.description:
Manages overstimulation in a more organized manner, e.g.,
disengages, walks away

7EBBB8AC6B834683848C2DE9375B6852.description: Communicates needs more thoroughly, e.g., “I am hungry”

E7A0BA354DC1496EBA6AA967A7B34610.description:
Recognizes patterns throughout the day, e.g., grabs a pillow and
blanket after lunch, when it is nap time

08585343E8314E1185342D5F879BF0D9.description:
Uses movement to express an emotion, e.g., jumps up and down
when excited, stomps feet when upset

72C8BE7A57B049C4A83660A1E5E80086.description: Calms down in order to sit and read a book with a caregiver

D43DC449C2DE485F9D880D038CC116F7.description:
Begins to have an awareness of bodily functions and begins to
demonstrate an interest in toileting, e.g., recognizes a “potty”

8C931D01FFCE4CF7AC030B5ECDACACC6.description:
Communicates needs with one or two words, e.g., says or
gestures “milk” for “I want milk”

179A86C9454448D6A0A0DF627D6687BB.description:
Becomes frustrated and displays regressive behaviors when
overstimulated, e.g., temper tantrums

CC888820D4FE448A98342548DC008453.description:
Uses gestures and symbolic actions to demonstrate feelings and
needs, e.g., lays head on caregiver’s lap when tired

B49BFF5826E84767A3CDEAE11C9545E4.description: Increased desire for independence and control

CAD36B2B076949A89891331446CD231E.description:
Begins to exhibit certain behaviors when overstimulated and/or
unfocused, e.g., becomes aggressive, lashes out, bites

484EED063F9C42808C3EBEB53D0BD0C5.description: Communicates with a wide range of signals as crying diminishes, e.g., smiles, gestures, uses words

4F15E2475B7F4CCCAF2886686EA9F008.description:
Increasingly organized and consolidated internal schedule for
sleep/wake, elimination, and feeding, e.g., decreases the number
of naps but extends the length of the naps

8A7E9AB7745942B4AE0B03ED76942A84.description:
Demonstrates consistent sleeping and feeding times throughout
the day

83A70A397B324E9CAFD5DAF61039A90E.description: Uses sucking to assist in sleeping

3D1D55B6E75D49B8AE493F170D99338A.description:
Disengages when overstimulated, e.g., turns head, glances away,
falls asleep, spits up

AE90A17B51544A598FFF1C17E4A14E68.description: Signals for needs, e.g., cries when hungry, arches back in discomfort

44CC8B3C7CC645A3B681373845452CF3.description:
Begins to demonstrate a pattern in sleep-wake and feeding
cycles

56D14EA795B44A0D9E2F375DE24ADB07.description:
Children demonstrate the emerging ability to process stimuli, focus and sustain attention, and maintain engagement in
accordance with social and cultural contexts.
